docs.snippet: PARIS OPEN  Becker Advances To Face Sampras    Boris Becker beat the Australian doubles star Mark Woodforde, 6-2, 6-4, yesterday in his opening match at the Paris Open and will play top-ranked Pete Sampras in the second round.     Becker won five...
docs.lead_paragraph: PARIS OPEN Becker Advances To Face Sampras Boris Becker beat the Australian doubles star Mark Woodforde, 6-2, 6-4, yesterday in his opening match at the Paris Open and will play top-ranked Pete Sampras in the second round. Becker won five straight games in the first set after being down 1-2, then came back from a 1-3 deficit in the second set.

docs.snippet: Several years ago, Dr. Marion Oettinger Jr., an anthropologist in Texas, curated an exhibition on the folk art of Latin America for the Museum of American Folk Art in New York. Assembling that show had a profound influence on him, he recalled: ''I...
docs.lead_paragraph: Several years ago, Dr. Marion Oettinger Jr., an anthropologist in Texas, curated an exhibition on the folk art of Latin America for the Museum of American Folk Art in New York. Assembling that show had a profound influence on him, he recalled: ''I did three years of field work. After traveling to 17 Latin American countries, I began to see some blatant similarities in the objects, artistically speaking.'' In 1988, for example, he visited rural Tabasco, Mexico, where in a church he discovered a series of wooden model ships, some from as early as the 18th century, hanging from the ceiling of the nave. ''These delightful carvings,'' he later wrote, ''were votive offerings left by sailors and fishermen in appreciation for safe delivery from storms.'' On trips to Colombia, Peru, Venezuela and Oaxaca, Mexico, Dr. Oettinger found similar ex votos (votive offerings) -- ''charming testaments to the power of the saints to save endangered sailors.'' He assumed that these boats were an art form native only to Latin America.
docs.abstract: Antiques column on exhibit of folk art of Spain and the Americas, now at San Antonio Museum of Art; curator Dr Marion Oettinger Jr comments; show's other stops in US noted (S)

headline.main: Antiques; Folk Art: The Spanish Connection

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Lost in the ''fast track'' debate (news article, Nov. 11) is the effect of protectionism on the poor, particularly in the developing world. So far, globalization has largely been a rich countries' game. The Uruguay Round of trade...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Lost in the ''fast track'' debate (news article, Nov. 11) is the effect of protectionism on the poor, particularly in the developing world. So far, globalization has largely been a rich countries' game. The Uruguay Round of trade talks left tariffs on exports of the least developed countries 30 percent higher than the world average and agricultural subsidies in industrialized countries at roughly 50 percent of value. This shuts out products that the poor could efficiently produce and sell.
docs.abstract: Merrill Smith letter disputes November 11 article on debate over fast-track trade legislation (S)

headline.main: Dropping Barriers Can Rescue Third World Poor

docs.snippet: Arthur Eric Gropp, a champion of closer United States-Latin American ties and a former library director for the Organization of American States, died on Nov. 8 at his home in Greenbelt, Md. He was 94.    Mr. Gropp led the Columbus Memorial Library at...
docs.lead_paragraph: Arthur Eric Gropp, a champion of closer United States-Latin American ties and a former library director for the Organization of American States, died on Nov. 8 at his home in Greenbelt, Md. He was 94. Mr. Gropp led the Columbus Memorial Library at O.A.S. headquarters in Washington from 1950 until he retired in 1968. He earlier led a project of the American Library Association and the Rockefeller Foundation in Uruguay to give Montevideo an American library, the Biblioteca Artigas-Washington, which he served as director from 1942 to 1950.
docs.abstract: Arthur Eric Gropp, champion of closer US-Latin American ties and former library director for Organization of American States, dies at age 94 (S)

headline.main: A.E. Gropp, 94, Librarian of Latin America

docs.snippet: Julio de Quesada, the head of Citibank's operations in Mexico, did not know that the chairman of a Mexican bank he was negotiating to buy had installed a secret door and an underground tunnel in a palatial mansion in northern Mexico.    Mr. de...
docs.lead_paragraph: Julio de Quesada, the head of Citibank's operations in Mexico, did not know that the chairman of a Mexican bank he was negotiating to buy had installed a secret door and an underground tunnel in a palatial mansion in northern Mexico. Mr. de Quesada never guessed that the Mexican banker, Jorge Lankenau Rocha, would one day admit to the police that he had used the tunnel to escape from 20 rifle-toting officers surrounding the estate.
docs.abstract: Citicorp's agreement in August to buy high-profile Mexican bank from Jorge Lankenau Rocha looked like good deal; it still may be, but in months since acquisition of Banca Confia was announced, it has become major headache for Citibank and its Mexican director Julio de Quesada; Lankenau has been arrested and charged with fraud, and deal has become lightning rod for Mexican criticism of foreign corporate ownership; Citibank paid $45 million for Confia and has injected up to $175 million in capital into the bank; Confia is a plum for Citibank; it has 200 branches throughout the country and reputation for service that is rare in Mexico; acquisition fits Citibank's desire to get into street-corner banking in Mexico and to become banker to world's rising middle class; chart on status of 18 Mexican banks since collapse of peso in late; photos (L)

headline.main: For Citibank, A Problem Plum; Mexican Deal Survives, Despite Fraud Case and Political Turmoil

docs.snippet: THE MAN ON THE telephone, 10 years ago, spoke Spanish with a Rioplatense accent. (The Rio de la Plata separates Argentina and Uruguay.) ''This is Astor Piazzolla, and I would like you to conduct my next musical in New York,'' he said. ''Sure,'' I...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE MAN ON THE telephone, 10 years ago, spoke Spanish with a Rioplatense accent. (The Rio de la Plata separates Argentina and Uruguay.) ''This is Astor Piazzolla, and I would like you to conduct my next musical in New York,'' he said. ''Sure,'' I answered, ''this is Christopher Columbus.'' Fortunately, he did not hold it against me. This was a young man's dream, being called by an idol of his adolescence, working with him in the flesh. As a child of Uruguay, I did not care much for old-style tango, but Piazzolla was something else. He was hip, cool, sexy and evocative.
docs.abstract: Pablo Zinger reviews CD's of tango music of late Astor Piazzolla; photo (M)

headline.main: It Took One to Tango: Piazzolla

docs.snippet: Delta Air Lines announced an ambitious Latin American expansion plan today aimed at making Atlanta an alternative gateway to the region.    The carrier said it would begin nonstop service in April between Atlanta and four Central American nations,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Delta Air Lines announced an ambitious Latin American expansion plan today aimed at making Atlanta an alternative gateway to the region. The carrier said it would begin nonstop service in April between Atlanta and four Central American nations, and it hoped to add service to up to 19 Latin American cities during the next four years.
docs.abstract: Delta Air Lines announces ambitious Latin American expansion plan aimed at making Atlanta, Ga, an alternative gateway to region (S)

headline.main: Delta to Expand In Latin America

docs.snippet: Although he acknowledged that work remained to be done, President Clinton gave a remarkably upbeat assessment of his Administration's foreign-policy achievements at his news conference on Tuesday, a kind of sneak preview of his 1998 State of the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Although he acknowledged that work remained to be done, President Clinton gave a remarkably upbeat assessment of his Administration's foreign-policy achievements at his news conference on Tuesday, a kind of sneak preview of his 1998 State of the Union Message. The picture was all but unrecognizable to many in Washington foreign-policy circles, including a number of senior Administration officials. Asked what he made of it, one such official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, rolled his eyes and replied, ''The President was just having a little political fun.''
docs.abstract: Analysis of Pres Clinton's upbeat assessment of his Administration's foreign policy achievements at recent news conference; picture is all but unrecognizable to many in Washington foreign-policy circles, who are puzzled by breadth of his claims at time when American foreign relations have hit bad patch (M)

headline.main: Clinton on His Foreign Policy: A Rose-Tinted World
